intro: Haplopappus virgatus, commonly known as the slender pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive bracts. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, such as deserts and rocky soils. Its leaves are narrow and linear, and it produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in the spring. The plant is adapted to withstand drought conditions and has a low-growing, sprawling habit.
